awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Measuring the Impact and Diffusion of Open Source Software Innovation on Contributor and Project Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Open-Source Software (OSS) is developed, maintained, and extended through the contribution of independent developers as well as individuals and groups from universities, government research institutions, businesses, and nonprofits. Many OSS projects are developed in free repositories, and the information embedded in these repositories - including the code, contributors, and development activity - is publicly available. However, the extent and impacts of OSS on the economy and innovation are currently unknown, and the creation and use of OSS highlight an aspect of technology diffusion and flow not captured in science and technology indicators. The goals of this project are to discover, collect, and use publicly available non-survey data sources on OSS and to test the feasibility of developing methods to measure the impact and diffusion of OSS innovation. The project will evaluate OSS through development of rigorous, repeatable, and scalable methods and metrics. The outputs of this effort — unique data sets, code, and the resulting analyses of the interactions among contributors and projects — advance our nascent knowledge about OSS, including the patterns and dynamics of collaborations, influential actors, prevailing topics, and diffusion. Developed measures will complement existing indicators on peer-reviewed publications and patents. Our framework could apply to other aspects of open science, such as shared data available in public repositories.

To address our core questions, we propose (i) to characterize the OSS ecosystem by analyzing available information on OSS projects (creation and use), and developers (institutions, sectors, and countries); (ii) to represent the interactions using networks of contributors (through collaborations between developers) and networks of OSS projects (through reuses across projects and shared contributors) and to analyze their structural features; (iii) to develop methods to measure the impact of projects and developers using network-based and OSS-based measures (e.g., downloads); (iv) to study the diffusion of OSS innovation within and across institutions, sectors and countries; and (v) to bring forward a unique and novel data product combining various data sources on OSS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Open-source software (OSS) is a vital driver of innovation, collaboration, and economic development, impacting industries, governments, and academia worldwide. Many OSS projects are developed in free repositories, with the information embedded in these repositories—including the code, contributors, and development activity—being publicly available. Despite its widespread use, the extent and impacts of OSS on the economy and innovation remain largely unknown. The creation and use of OSS highlight aspects of technology diffusion and flow that are not captured in existing science and technology indicators.

This project explored the OSS ecosystem to better understand its value, contributions, and societal impact, bridging disciplines such as economics, public policy, bibliometrics, data science, gender studies, and diversity research. Our research addressed the following questions: (i) What is the value and cost of open-source software projects in the United States? (ii) How much does the U.S. Federal Government contribute to public open-source software? (iii) How can we attribute credit and measure the impact of open-source software using bibliometric methods? (iv) Are there gender differences in open-source software development?

We developed a novel framework to estimate investment in OSS using data from GitHub, the world’s largest open-source platform. Our analysis calculated U.S. OSS investment at $37.8 billion in 2019, with a net stock value of $74.3 billion, providing a first-of-its-kind economic analysis aligned with the national accounting framework. Our in-depth study of federal OSS contributions, using data from Code.gov, highlighted significant investments ($407 million in 2021) and demonstrated the government’s critical role in fostering OSS innovation. We also applied bibliometric methods to attribute OSS contributions at the national and developer levels, revealing that developers from the U.S., Germany, and the U.K. dominate OSS contributions to Python and R programming languages.

We explored gender disparities in OSS contributions, finding that the proportion of female contributors increased from 5% in 2008 to 11% in 2020. Teams have grown more diverse over time: the average OSS package team was 1%-2% female during 2008–2014 and 4%-5% female during 2016–2020. However, the absolute difference in the number of male and female developers has grown, underscoring ongoing challenges in achieving gender parity.

This project fostered collaboration between academic institutions, government agencies, and private organizations (e.g., New York University, Harvard Business School, the National Science Foundation, the Bureau of Economic Analysis, GitHub, and Westat). It also inspired new initiatives, such as GitHub’s Innovation Graph, which provides insights into global software development trends.

A project website (https://oss.quarto.pub/website/) was developed to disseminate findings, data, and code. This platform enables institutions to access and utilize project outputs, fostering scientific communication and collaboration. The project also created a unique dataset that integrates data from multiple sources, including GitHub and Code.gov. This dataset serves as a resource for institutions studying or leveraging OSS in scientific, policy, or technological applications. By making this dataset publicly accessible, the project strengthens the information infrastructure available to universities, research organizations, and government agencies.

Moreover, the project provided reproducible code and resources to the academic and research community, facilitating broader adoption of OSS research practices. We also developed GitRipper, a publicly available data collection tool that aids researchers in gathering and analyzing OSS data from GitHub. These resources reduce barriers to entry for institutions looking to engage in OSS research by providing pre-built, reliable tools.
